body: @tommcdo I think that this issue is the same as #1104

@tommcdo this is really interesting situation you have.
I encountered the same for a few times and was also surprised.

But what if you look at it this way:
- by testing `assertThat(mySet.contains("foo"))` you test the concrete implementation of `contains` method of the given object
- by testing `assertThat(mySet).contains("foo")` you test that given object contains exactly specific object.
as said in javadoc 
>  Verifies that the actual group contains the given values, in any order

@filiphr I think it is slightly different

It looks most general interface where a custom comparator can be supplied is [`SortedSet`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/SortedSet.html).

Would it be too naive to simply overload `Assertions.assertThat(SortedSet)`?

```java
public static <ELEMENT> IterableAssert<ELEMENT> assertThat(SortedSet<? extends ELEMENT> actual) {                                                                                
  return new IterableAssert<>(actual).usingElementComparator(actual.comparator());                                                                                                                                          
}
```

@tommcdo that is a nicely short possibility, I think the only drawback is that if your `SortedSet` is declared as a `Set` that won't work, it would select `assertThat(Iterable<? extends ELEMENT> actual)` instead of `assertThat(SortedSet<? extends ELEMENT> actual)`.
@joel-costigliola Good call, that would be non-ideal.
We might get away with the limitation I mentioned by checking if the runtime type of actual is a `SortedSet`.

issue.title: ClassCastException when using assertion on SortedSet and extracting method

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM
